speaker: Doctor
text: What is the duration of the ulcerative lesion on your leg?

speaker: Patient
text: It's been present for about a month now. It started as a small red spot and has grown larger since then.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in the color or appearance of the lesion since it first appeared?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, the lesion has developed a central necrotic base and the borders have become purplish and irregular. It looks quite different from when it first appeared.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any fever, chills, or systemic symptoms since the lesion appeared?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I haven't experienced any fever, chills, or other systemic symptoms since the lesion appeared. It seems to be localized to my leg.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any recent injuries or insect bites in the area where the lesion developed?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, I recall having an ant bite at that site before the lesion developed. It was a small bite, but shortly after, the lesion started to form.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any drainage or discharge from the lesion? If so, what does it look like?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, there has been some drainage from the lesion. It appears to be a yellowish fluid, and sometimes it has a slightly foul odor.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any recent travel history or exposure to any animals or environments that could be relevant?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, I recently returned from a visit to Wisconsin about two months ago. I spent time outdoors, but I didn't have any direct exposure to animals.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any pain or tenderness in the area surrounding the lesion?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, the area around the lesion is quite painful and tender to the touch. It feels uncomfortable, especially when I move my leg.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any swelling or redness in the surrounding area of the lesion?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, there is some swelling around the lesion, and the skin appears red and inflamed. It feels warm to the touch as well.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any previous skin conditions or infections in the past?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't had any significant skin conditions or infections in the past. My skin has generally been healthy until now.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any changes in sensation, such as numbness or tingling, in the area around the lesion?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't noticed any numbness or tingling around the lesion. The pain is more prominent, but no changes in sensation.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any lymphadenopathy, such as swollen lymph nodes in your groin or thigh area?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't noticed any swollen lymph nodes in my groin or thigh area. The only symptoms I've been experiencing are localized to the lesion on my leg.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any recent exposure to soil or water, particularly in rural or wooded areas?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't had any specific exposure to soil or water recently, aside from my time outdoors in Wisconsin. I mostly stayed on trails and didn't go into any bodies of water.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any changes in your overall health, such as weight loss or fatigue, since the lesion appeared?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't experienced any weight loss or significant fatigue since the lesion appeared. My overall health feels stable aside from the issues with my leg.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any other skin lesions or rashes elsewhere on your body since this one appeared?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I haven't noticed any other skin lesions or rashes on my body. This is the only one that has developed recently.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any recent vaccinations or medical procedures that could be relevant to your current condition?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't had any recent vaccinations or medical procedures that I can recall. My last significant medical intervention was for anterior uveitis about eight months ago.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any itching or burning sensations in or around the lesion?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I haven't experienced any itching or burning sensations around the lesion. The pain is more prominent, but there's no itching at all.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in your overall skin condition, such as dryness or flakiness, in the area surrounding the lesion?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't noticed any dryness or flakiness in the area surrounding the lesion. The skin appears red and inflamed, but it feels more moist than dry.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any history of immunosuppression or are you currently taking any medications that could affect your immune system?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, I have a history of Crohn's disease, and I'm currently taking medications like mesalamine and corticosteroids for my condition. I also take insulin for my diabetes, which may affect my immune system.

speaker: Doctor
text: Given your history of Crohn's disease and current medications, I would like to assess the lesion further. REQUEST TEST: Skin_Biopsy.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Histopathology findings show neutrophilic infiltration without infection, consistent with pyoderma gangrenosum.

speaker: Doctor
text: DIAGNOSIS READY: Pyoderma gangrenosum.
